Award.AwardTitle: US/Chinese Collaborative Study: Investigation of Bottom Water Formation in Prydz Bay, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Processess governing the formation of Antarctic bottom water (AABW) in the Indian Ocean sector of the Southern Ocean remain poorly described. As with AABW formation in more well studied regions of the Antarctic continent, global climate impacts of the source regions of this dense, cold water that help drive the global ocean thermohaline circulation are uncertain. A combination of (annual) continental shelf and slope moorings, seasonal (summer) hydrographic surveys on board the Chinese icebreaker M/V Xuelong, together with synthesis of historic and satellite data will be used to better constrain shelf processes and the atmosphere-ocean-ice interactions in the Prydz Bay region.

Despite the seeming remoteness of the study site, changes in the formation rate of AABW could potentially have impact on northern hemisphere climate via effects on the global heat budget and through sea-level rise in the coming decades. The project additionally seeks to promote international collaboration between Chinese and US researchers. The data collected will be broadly disseminated to the oceanographic community through the National Oceanography Data Center and Chinese Arctic and Antarctic Data Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this award period, we conducted three seasons of field sampling in the Prydz Bay region, eastern Antarctic. Together we conducted 89 CTD stations and deployed 8 shelf moorings. Four  been recovered. All CTD data have been finally processed and are ready to contribute to data assimilations in the region. Meta data (sampling locations, time, depth) have been reported to US Antarctic Program Data Center. A project website has been extablished to descript this collaborative research: http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~xyuan/Prydz/index.html.

We found that the Prydz Bay shelf region does have high density shelf water (SW) in summer. The high salinity (>34.6) SW occurs in the mid and northern parts of the Prydz Depression. A high salinity SW is also observed near the Mackenzie polynya in winter, which is caused by brine rejection during the ice production process. However, the exports of SW from the Prydz Channel were observed but descending SW was limited to the top of 1500m on the slope and west of the Prydz Channel. No locally produced Antarctic Bottom Water (AABW) from the Prydz depression are exported to the deep basin directly north of Prydz Bay. Instead, AABW in this region majorly (72%) comes from the Weddell Sea and partly from the Adélie Land/Ross Sea regions. The later occurs mainly in the Princess Elizabeth Trough and near the slope in the eastern part of the study area. On the other hand, the newly formed AABW in the deep basin off Cape Darnley west of Prydz Bay is confirmed from our CTD samplings.  This AABW flows northwest along troughs on the slope and does not contribute to AABW north of Prydz Bay due to a topographic barrier. The results contribute to our understanding of the global overturning circulation and provide a physical background for biological and chemical studies in the region. We produced three conference presentations based on above results. Three manuscripts are being drafted currently. In addition, Yuan also participated other studies that are relevant to the project during this award period. Five publications were published.

During this award period, Yuan supervised a visiting Ph.D. student (Yongming Sun) from Ocean University of China, who investigated the long-term changes in watermass properties using historical data and our recent surveys in this region. Sun was also trained at Lamont for the CTD data post-cruise processing. Yuan also supervised a summer intern, Jin Guo, from Columbia University. Guo worked on analyzing surface forcing in the Prydz Bay Region.  In addition, Yuan supervised a high school summer intern Eric Sun who  worked on the project website development and updates.  As an outreach effort, Yuan participated a tourist cruise to the Antarctic in December 2013 as a scientist on board and presented current Antarctic sciences and its relevance to the global climate system to a group of entrepreneurs, economists, government officials, artists and social science scholars.
